Award.AwardTitle: SaTC: STARSS: Small: Wireless, Battery-less, Monolithic Tamper Detector for Semiconductor Chip Authenticity

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research explores the feasibility of a submillimeter-sized, battery-less, tamper detecting chip that can be placed inside a semiconductor package through a droplet ejector, and which can be interrogated wirelessly from the outside of the semiconductor package for detecting any recorded tampering activity. The research paves foundational technology for a paradigm-shifting concept of individualized detection and recording of tampering activities to ensure authenticity of semiconductor chips. Also, the packaging technology based on a droplet ejector opens up a brand-new packaging approach for semiconductor chips. Thus, the research greatly impacts many industries including semiconductor industry.

The research is to study the feasibility of a single-chip detector that (1) can record any invasive semiconductor-chip-package tampering activity without need of a battery, (2) can be placed inside semiconductor chip packages through a nozzleless droplet ejector, and (3) can be wirelessly interrogated without need to open up the semiconductor package. With a piezoelectric film supported on a non-piezoelectric cantilever with a proof mass at its free end, electrical voltage is generated (1) when there is vibrational energy due to de-packaging or de-layering and (2) when there is heat due to de-soldering or de-layering. The electrical voltage (induced by vibration due to de-packaging or de-layering) breaks down another piezoelectric film used for a passive Surface Acoustic Wave (SAW) resonator built on a silicon substrate, leaving a permanent mark on the SAW resonator, which no longer works as a resonator, thus permanently recording the tampering activity. The SAW resonator is interrogated wirelessly with radio frequency signal.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have established the foundational technology for Wireless, Battery-less, Monolithic Tamper Detector for Semiconductor Chip Authenticity. Particularly, we have demonstrated a proof-of-concept sensor that can detect and record an invasive semiconductor-chip-package tampering activity without need of a battery and can be wirelessly interrogated without having to open up the semiconductor package, based on passive Radio-Frequency Identification (RFID) with a 7.5 GHz High-overtone Bulk Acoustic Resonator (HBAR). The HBAR is connected to a pyroelectric energy converter (PEC) based on Lithium Niobate (LiNbO3) which can generate high enough voltage and charge to electrically breakdown the HBAR when temperature is raised to a de-soldering temperature. Our measurements have validated the concept that we can permanently alter the high frequency resonance characteristics of the HBAR through dielectric breakdown caused by a tampering activity.

The following findings of ours have broader impacts on semiconductor supply-chain security and manufacturing as well as passive RFID: (1) pyro/piezoelectric LiNbO3 can generate enough voltage and charge for leaving a permanent mark on passive RFID in response to temperature change, even though the size and thickness are reduced to a subminiature level; (2) high Q HBAR offers a RFID tag which is very difficult to reproduce; (3) nozzle-less, acoustic ejection provides unprecedented capability to semiconductor manufacturing and packaging without robotic pick-and-placement.

The experimental results obtained through this research indicate that the tamper detector, when it is fully miniaturized, will offer the benefits of markedly (1) reduced cost and time to authenticate semiconductor chips, (2) improved robustness and accuracy of such an authentication, and (3) increased costs on the counterfeiter’s end to scavenge semiconductor chips from printed circuit boards.
